    <item>
      <title>John Major: EU leave campaign at risk of ‘divisive’ immigration stance</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/john-major-eu-leave-campaigners-risk-turning-into-ukip</link>
      <description><p>Former prime minister will tell leaders of Brexit side that heavy emphasis on issue could lead to them ‘morphing into Ukip’</p><p>Sir John Major will tell those leading the campaign for Britain to leave the EU that they risk morphing into Ukip through their heavy emphasis on immigration.</p><p>In a speech on Friday that will be seen as a thinly veiled criticism of Boris Johnson, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/apr/19/michael-goves-points-based-system-immigration-fantasy">Michael Gove</a> and other senior Tory leave supporters, the former prime minister will accuse the anti-EU camp of crossing the line with its arguments in a way that risks dividing communities.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/john-major-eu-leave-campaigners-risk-turning-into-ukip">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>BBC may have shown bias against Corbyn, says former trust chair</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-bias-labour-sir-michael-lyons</link>
      <description><p>Sir Michael Lyons tells The World at One that he could understand people’s concerns about a loss of editorial impartiality</p><p>The BBC may have bowed to political pressure to show bias against Labour and Jeremy Corbyn, a former chair of the BBC Trust has said.</p><p>Sir Michael Lyons, who chaired the trust from 2007 to 2011 and is a former Labour councillor, claimed that there had been “some quite extraordinary attacks on the elected leader of the Labour party”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-bias-labour-sir-michael-lyons">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/conservatives-court-campaign-spending-details-electoral-commission</link>
      <description><p>Electoral Commission asks high court for disclosure order after party fails to provide details amid claims it broke spending rules</p><p>The Conservative party is being taken to court by the election watchdog amid claims that it breached spending rules.</p><p>The Electoral Commission has applied to the high court for a document and information disclosure order after party chiefs failed to provide requested details. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/conservatives-court-campaign-spending-details-electoral-commission">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>UK steel boost as MEPs oppose giving China market economy status</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/european-parliament-votes-against-china-market-economy-status-uk-steel-industry</link>
      <description><p>European parliament votes against plan steelmakers believe would kill off industry by opening door to glut of cheap steel</p><p>UK steelmakers have cheered a European parliament resolution opposing plans that they believe would kill off the industry by permanently opening the floodgates to cheap Chinese steel.</p><p>MEPs passed a resolution saying China should not be granted market economy status by Brussels, which could make it harder for officials to impose punitive tariffs on Chinese steel. Brussels is due to make a ruling this year.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/european-parliament-votes-against-china-market-economy-status-uk-steel-industry">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Break up the Treasury, says Iain Duncan Smith</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/break-up-the-treasury-says-iain-duncan-smith</link>
      <description><p>Former cabinet minister says dominant department ‘run by 27-year-olds with lack of vision’ is stifling investment and growth<br></p><p>Iain Duncan Smith, the former work and pensions secretary, has said the Treasury needs to be broken up because it has been responsible for short-term low productivity and is run by 27-year-olds with no collective memory.</p><p>Duncan Smith said the department sought to dictate every policy across the government: “I think it has to be broken up; I have reached that conclusion. The worst thing we have in Britain is the Treasury.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/break-up-the-treasury-says-iain-duncan-smith">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>World leaders pledge to tackle corruption at London summit – as it happened</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2016/may/12/david-cameron-london-anti-corruption-summit-live</link>
      <description><p>Six countries sign up to public register of beneficial ownership but campaigners criticise British territories who will only share information behind closed doors</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T15:16:29.413Z">4.16pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>We are fighting a battle, all of us. Corruption, writ large, is as much of an enemy, because it destroys nation states, as some of the extremists we are fighting or the other challenges we face.</p><p>ONE calls on countries who attended the anti-corruption summit to urgently implement gold standard policies that ensure fair play. To root out corruption, we need committed and robust action, crucially including the public disclosure of beneficial ownership of companies and trusts.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T14:58:21.418Z">3.58pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Cameron is asked about the need to push overseas territories and crown dependencies to do more to be open and transparent over the registers of beneficial ownership.</p><p>He says the territories have come a long way in agreeing to the automatic sharing of information, and says that goes further than what the United States and some European countries have agreed.</p><p>If you think how far they have come in the last few weeks and months, I am convinced we will get them all over that bar [of automatic sharing of registers, which British Virgin Islands has not signed up to do].</p><p>The gold standard which I will push for as long as I have breath in my body, is public registers. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2016/may/12/david-cameron-london-anti-corruption-summit-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Unqualified daughter of minister teaches in his academy schools</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/education/2016/may/12/unqualified-daughter-of-minister-teaches-in-his-academy-schools</link>
      <description><p>Daughter of schools minister Lord Nash is also helping draw up new curriculum for Future Academies – set up by Nash and his wife</p><p>An academy chain set up by the schools minister <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/education/2014/nov/11/academies-minister-lord-nash-breaching-governance-guidelines">Lord Nash</a> is allowing his unqualified and unpaid daughter to teach history and help draw up a new curriculum, prompting concerns from parents and a teachers’ union.</p><p><a href="http://www.futureacademies.org/">Future Academies</a> in Pimlico, central London, was set up by the minister in charge of academies and his wife, Caroline. They both maintain prominent roles in the organisation. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/education/2016/may/12/unqualified-daughter-of-minister-teaches-in-his-academy-schools">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>US and UK urge banks to do business with Iran</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/us-and-uk-urge-banks-to-do-business-with-iran</link>
      <description><p>Iranian president Hassan Rouhani is under pressure from hardliners as lifting of sanctions fails to live up to expectations</p><p>An attempt by the US and UK governments to persuade European banks to do more business in Iran in the wake of last year’s nuclear deal, appears to have fallen on deaf ears.</p><p>Senior representatives from nine major banks listened on Thursday to appeals from the US secretary of state, John Kerry, and the British foreign secretary, Philip Hammond, urging them to help finance expanded trade with Iran following the lifting of sanctions under the agreement sealed in Vienna last July. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/us-and-uk-urge-banks-to-do-business-with-iran">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>David Cameron to avoid facing Johnson or Gove in Brexit debates</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/robert-peston-vote-leave-mad-slur-eu-referendum-debate</link>
      <description><p>Culture secretary John Whittingdale says ITV should face Ofcom over decision to make Nigel Farage the voice of the leave campaign</p><p>David Cameron looks set to avoid facing either Boris Johnson or Michael Gove in the EU referendum live television debates, despite the leave campaign threatening to complain to Ofcom or launch legal action.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>The prime minister has so far agreed to two events – an interview with Sky and another ITV interview back-to-back with the Ukip leader, Nigel Farage.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/robert-peston-vote-leave-mad-slur-eu-referendum-debate">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/eu-referendum">EU referendum</category>

    <item>
      <title>Welsh assembly standoff leaves voters baffled</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/welsh-assembly-standoff-plaid-cymru-labour</link>
      <description><p>Plaid Cymru loyalists in Rhondda valley are bemused at deadlock between party and Labour over who will be first minister</p><p>In Cardiff, Welsh assembly politicians and their aides were hammering out deals, exchanging insults in the press and attempting to compromise on a deadlock that has prevented the creation of a new government.</p><p>Twenty miles down the road, at the Lion Inn in Treorchy, high in the Rhondda valley, drinkers were frankly baffled that their new constituency member, the Plaid Cymru leader Leanne Wood, had very nearly become first minister despite only having a fifth of the assembly in her party.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/welsh-assembly-standoff-plaid-cymru-labour">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Billionaire Brexit supporter says UK should emulate Singapore</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/billionaire-brexit-supporter-says-uk-should-emulate-singapore</link>
      <description><p>Campaign donor Peter Hargreaves says leaving EU would cut red tape and make Britain more globally competitive </p><p>The billionaire donor bankrolling the Brexit campaign Peter Hargreaves has said the EU is too dominated by France and Germany , and believes Singapore is the best business model for Britain outside the European Union. </p><p>The businessman also said a steep fall in sterling could be good for the country, and that some workers’ rights – such as part-time employment, flexitime and extended maternity leave – have gone too far.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/billionaire-brexit-supporter-says-uk-should-emulate-singapore">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>'No evidence' linking Edward Heath claims to dropped prosecution</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/no-evidence-edward-heath-dropped-prosecution-police-watchdog</link>
      <description><p>Police watchdog says there is no evidence prosecution of brothel keeper was abandoned after allegations against ex-PM</p><p>There is no evidence that a police force attempted to cover up allegations of child sex abuse against Sir Edward Heath in the 1990s, the police watchdog has found.</p><p>The Independent Police Complaints Commission said last year it was investigating concerns that Wiltshire police abandoned a prosecution against a brothel keeper in February 1994 because she threatened to expose the former prime minister as a paedophile.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/no-evidence-edward-heath-dropped-prosecution-police-watchdog">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Eurosceptic SNP voters could influence EU referendum result, polling data shows</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/scotland-blog/2016/may/12/eurosceptic-snp-voters-could-influence-eu-referendum-result-polling-data-shows</link>
      <description><p>A series of polls show a large minority of Scottish National party voters are Eurosceptics, giving Nicola Sturgeon a political headache as the referendum campaign begins<br></p><p>Last week’s Holyrood election gave Nicola Sturgeon a clear cut victory and mandate, taking 63 parliamentary seats, just two short of a majority. But barely has that election finished than the European referendum campaign will begin, and with it another tough challenge for the Scottish National party leader.</p><p>Almost a third of her voters oppose one of her key policies, that Scotland and the UK should stay in the EU. A series of opinion polls has shown that SNP voters are the largest bloc in favour of quitting the EU in Scotland. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/scotland-blog/2016/may/12/eurosceptic-snp-voters-could-influence-eu-referendum-result-polling-data-shows">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Fleet Street 'gossip': Chinese paper plays down Queen's attack on 'rude' officials</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/chinese-media-dismisses-gossip-over-queens-attack-on-behaviour-of-beijing-officials</link>
      <description><p>Communist party newspaper says complaint by monarch of officials’ rudeness were ‘hyped up’ by British media</p><p>The Communist party’s best-selling tabloid has accused the British media of “hyping up” the Queen’s comments about “rude” Chinese officials and spreading malicious “gossip” in order to hurt ties between Beijing and London. <br></p><p>Beijing would not confirm whether <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/uk-golden-era-china-in-balance-queen-comments-rude">its “golden” friendship with Britain </a>was still alive on Wednesday after the Queen was caught on camera lamenting the behaviour of Chinese officials involved in President Xi Jinping’s state visit to Britain in 2015. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/chinese-media-dismisses-gossip-over-queens-attack-on-behaviour-of-beijing-officials">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Only 35% of newly elected MSPs are female, and now campaigners are demanding tough action on gender balance in the Scottish parliament</p><p>Well, that was disappointing. </p><p>As 129 freshly elected MSPs are sworn in on Thursday morning, the group photos of the new party cohorts say it all: many men in suits, fewer flashes of colour from the minority of women, and don’t even bother getting started on the lack of non-white faces.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/scotland-blog/2016/may/12/holyrood-2016-scottish-parliament-gender-gap">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>David Cameron to introduce new corporate money-laundering offence</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/david-cameron-corporate-money-laundering-offence-anti-corruption-summit</link>
      <description><p><strong>Exclusive:</strong> prime minister brings in charge of failing to prevent fraud or money laundering as UK prepares to host anti-corruption summit</p><p>David Cameron is to counter claims that his campaign against international corruption is hobbled by London’s reputation as the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/jul/25/london-housing-market-launder-offshore-tax-havens">money laundering capital</a> of the world by introducing a new corporate offence for executives who fail to prevent fraud or money laundering inside their companies.</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/11/fight-against-corruption-begins-with-political-will">Writing in the Guardian</a> before Thursday’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/04/cameron-to-propose-global-anti-corruption-agency-at-summit">anti-corruption summit</a> in the capital, the prime minister reveals plans to require all foreign companies buying property in the UK to disclose their true owners in a public register for the first time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/david-cameron-corporate-money-laundering-offence-anti-corruption-summit">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/consent-key-immigration-debate-boris-johnson-vote-leave-bus-tour</link>
      <description><p>On first day of Vote Leave bus tour, Tory MP says numbers should not have been so high without voters’ agreement</p><p>Boris Johnson has argued that immigration could remain high in the event of Britain leaving the EU, if politicians can make a convincing case that new arrivals “turbo-charge” the economy.<br> </p><p>Visiting Cornwall on the first day of a Vote Leave bus tour, the former London mayor said he would like the UK to leave the EU so that it could turn away foreign workers who lack job offers or the right skills.<br> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/consent-key-immigration-debate-boris-johnson-vote-leave-bus-tour">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Replacing Trident will cost at least £205bn, campaigners say</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/replacing-trident-will-cost-at-least-205-billion-campaign-for-nuclear-disarmament</link>
      <description><p>Research from the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament also suggests cost will be much higher than previously estimated</p><p>The total cost of replacing the Trident nuclear missile system will come to at least £205bn, far more than previously estimated, according to figures drawn up by the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament (CND).</p><p>It has calculated the total on the basis of official figures, answers to parliamentary questions and previous costs of items including nuclear warheads and decommissioning nuclear reactors. It says it has not taken into account that past Ministry of Defence projects have frequently gone well over budget. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/may/12/replacing-trident-will-cost-at-least-205-billion-campaign-for-nuclear-disarmament">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Macintosh, who has to renounce party affiliation, becomes first Scottish Labour member elected to the speaker role</p><p>Ken Macintosh has become the first Scottish Labour member to be elected to the role of presiding officer of the Holyrood parliament.<br></p><p>The MSP won in the third round of a knockout ballot with 71 out of 128 votes, leaving 31 to Murdo Fraser of the Scottish Conservatives and 26 to the former Scottish Labour leader Johann Lamont.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/12/ken-macintosh-presiding-officer-scottish-parliament">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Political pressure making BBC biased against Labour and Corbyn, says former BBC chair – Politics live</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2016/may/12/eu-referendum-vote-leave-threatens-itv-after-farage-invited-to-debate-cameron-politics-live</link>
      <description><p>Rolling coverage of all the day’s political developments as they happen, including John Whittingdale’s Commons statement about the BBC white paper</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T15:06:04.984Z">4.06pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>There is a campaign representing those who think we should stay in the European Union, and the prime minister is speaking for them. And then there is a recognised campaign for those who think we would be better off outside the European Union, and yet the person who has been invited to debate with the prime minister does not come from that campaign. I find that extraordinary ... The idea that the prime minister has attempted to tell ITV who they should invite or who they should not invite seems to me extraordinary. </p><p>As the culture secretary, no. As a supporter of Vote Leave, I will understand why Vote Leave may wish to make a complaint.</p><p>Europe is the one continent in the world which was built not just on being a marketplace, but built on there being social rights and social responsibilities that we all accept. </p><p>I would think that we would send out a terrible message to the world if Britain - which has led the way in so many different respects in building the Europe that we have and in trying to make it a more humane and civilised place - simply walked away on June 23rd.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T14:37:58.038Z">3.37pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>The <strong>Conservative party</strong> has said that it has supplied the Electoral Commission with the information it requested as part of its investigation into the overspending allegations by lunchtime today. (See<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2016/may/12/eu-referendum-vote-leave-threatens-itv-after-farage-invited-to-debate-cameron-politics-live?page=with:block-57348a76e4b052e64fd5e939#block-57348a76e4b052e64fd5e939"> 2.57pm.) </a>A party spokesperson said: </p><p>We advised the Electoral Commission on 29th April that we would comply with their notices by 1pm today. There was no need for them to make this application to the high court.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2016/may/12/eu-referendum-vote-leave-threatens-itv-after-farage-invited-to-debate-cameron-politics-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Barnet’s chief executive, Andrew Travers, quickly resigned after last week’s voting fiasco. But perhaps the wider council is also to blame</p><p>Andrew Travers’ exit from the chief executive’s job at Barnet council after last Thursday’s voting <a href="https://www.barnet.gov.uk/citizen-home/news/Council-launches-investigation-into-election-problems.htmls">fiasco</a> was dramatic and swift.</p><p> But the Electoral Commission’s tests for a <a href="http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0007/141649/LGEW-MAY-RO-Part-A-role-and-responsibilities.pdf">returning officer</a> are rigorous and specific. The first is making it easy to vote. That wasn’t the case in the north London borough, where residents had to wait till 10.30 in the morning before polling stations opened with accurate lists.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/public-leaders-network/2016/may/13/barnet-chief-executive-andrew-travers-voting-blunder">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why Brexit would be the perfect gift for Vladimir Putin | Garry Kasparov</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/brexit-perfect-gift-vladimir-putin-eu</link>
      <description>An EU without Britain is exactly what the Russian president wants: a weakened institution with less power to confront his assaults on Europe’s borders<p>Politics often makes for strange bedfellows. Far-right parties in the UK and across Europe push for anything that will weaken the European Union – a goal shared by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/vladimir-putin" title="">Vladimir Putin</a> and Donald Trump. This week, their fellow Brexiteer Boris Johnson went as far as to repeat the Kremlin line that Europe is <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/09/boris-johnson-cameron-cant-cut-immigration-and-stay-in-eu" title="">partly to blame for Putin’s ongoing invasion of Ukraine</a>.</p><p>One does not expect clear policy statements from Trump or Johnson, but Putin’s reasoning is irrefutable. His goal is to weaken the institutions, including Nato and the EU, that could thwart his neo-Soviet ambitions. The Kremlin was in mourning when Scotland narrowly voted to stay in the UK. Putin sees Europe as his enemy and wants his&nbsp;adversaries to be divided, smaller and weaker.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/brexit-perfect-gift-vladimir-putin-eu">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why are we surprised by every populist politician? Voting for them can be a rational choice | Jason Wilson</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/why-are-we-surprised-by-every-populist-politician-voting-for-them-can-be-a-rational-choice</link>
      <description><p>Commentators perplexed at the inconsistencies of Donald Trump are missing the point. Populist leaders are defined more by their style than their ideology</p><p>For at least the last 20 years, democracies around the world have been regularly subject to a mounting series of populist insurgencies. From France to Venezuela, sharp-elbowed political actors from both the left and the right have railed against elites, flouted the table manners of liberal politics, and are increasingly meeting with electoral success. </p><p>But it seems that every time this happens, it takes commentators by surprise. Witness the worldwide reaction to the rise of Donald Trump. First came denial, with <a href="http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/dear-media-stop-freaking-out-about-donald-trumps-polls/">even empirical journalists resisting what polling is telling them</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/why-are-we-surprised-by-every-populist-politician-voting-for-them-can-be-a-rational-choice">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Cameron's intervention ends wrangling over BBC's future</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/david-cameron-intervention-bbc-white-paper-future</link>
      <description><p>Issues including licence fee and stars’ pay among ‘exhausting’ negotiations between culture secretary and broadcaster</p><p>After weeks of negotiations described as “bloody” and like “hand-to-hand combat” by BBC insiders, it took a personal intervention by the prime minister to end the wrangling over the contents of the white paper on the future of the broadcaster.</p><p>It was after the culture secretary, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-john-whittingdale-white-paper-star-pay-board">John Whittingdale, presented the white paper</a> to cabinet on Tuesday that David Cameron instructed his department to triple the level of pay subject to new disclosure rules from <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-white-paper-key-points-john-whittingdale">£150,000 to £450,000</a>. In doing so, he eased BBC concerns over the impact on most of its best-known news presenters, who might otherwise have been forced to defend their salaries on air.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/david-cameron-intervention-bbc-white-paper-future">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>With today’s BBC white paper one national disaster has been narrowly averted. But David Cameron’s weak leadership on the EU could yet unleash another<p>Be very clear about the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-white-paper-key-points-john-whittingdale" title="">BBC white paper</a>. In almost any other country in the world this would not be happening at all. Beyond Britain the BBC is universally revered. It stands for excellence and independence; and because of that excellence and independence, it stands above all for reliability.     <item>
      <title>The Guardian view on charter renewal: round one to the BBC | Editorial</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/guardian-view-on-bbc-charter-renewal</link>
      <description>The director general has won some big arguments but there is a lot in the detail that needs to be clarified before victory can be declared<p>For months past, the BBC has felt under threat. The institution that together with the NHS most inspires pride, that sustains Britain’s national identity and educates, informs and entertains us, seemed at the mercy of a culture secretary who has never hidden his dislike for what he has called a “<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/04/bbc-john-whittingdale-impartiality" title="">£4bn market intervention</a>”. Famous actors, leading writers and directors, musicians and even David Attenborough sprang to its defence. So, in their thousands, did the ordinary licence fee payer; <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/feb/04/dont-ignore-public-opinion-on-bbc-trust-chair-warns-culture-secretary" title="">almost 200,000 of them responded</a> to last year’s green paper. In this context, the white paper that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2016/may/12/eu-referendum-vote-leave-threatens-itv-after-farage-invited-to-debate-cameron-politics-live" title="">has finally emerged</a> felt like a win for the BBC and its director general, Tony Hall, who has been closely involved in the head-to-head negotiations of the past few weeks. It looked like a defeat for John Whittingdale, whose long flirtation with breaking up the BBC appears to have been delayed, if not defeated, by the combined might of a prime minister and a chancellor who have more sympathy for the corporation and no incentive to pick any more fights. There are some very welcome wins, but there are too many important details still to be decided to start the celebrations yet.</p><p>However, the BBC itself has moved too. It is willing to accept greater accountability. Ten&nbsp;years ago, the idea of regulation by Ofcom was resisted. Now it is to be accepted, and so is an extended remit for the National Audit Office. The reformed system of governance ought to be better at warning against some public catastrophes like the lavish pay-offs for senior staff, or the aborted <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-22651126" title="">£100m digital media initiative</a>, and for oversight if anything as grim as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/feb/25/serious-failings-bbc-jimmy-savile-abuse-72-woman-children-report" title="">the Savile disaster</a> struck again.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/guardian-view-on-bbc-charter-renewal">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Bank's warning of a Brexit double whammy is very handy for Osborne</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/banks-england-warning-brexit-double-whammy-osborne</link>
      <description><p>Chancellor will milk the Bank of England’s dire forecasts but the poor picture painted is as much due to UK structural weakness as EU referendum fears</p><p>Britain will make up its mind whether it wants to remain in the European Union in six weeks time, so it was inevitable that the last Bank of England inflation report before 23 June was dominated by the referendum.<br></p><p>And make no mistake, the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/bank-of-england-keeps-interest-rates-on-hold-as-brexit-fears-bite">warning from Threadneedle Street about the likely short-term consequences of a Brexit vote</a> – including a sharp fall in the value of the pound – is mightily handy for George Osborne. The Bank assumes that there will be a double whammy of weaker growth and higher inflation in the event of a vote to leave. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/banks-england-warning-brexit-double-whammy-osborne">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Britain’s accountability problem – hospitals are just the start | Anne Perkins</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/hillsborough-hospitals-public-bodies</link>
      <description><p>If holding vital public bodies to account is a mark of a civilised, functioning democracy, we’re not in a good place</p><p>Margaret Aspinall, whose 18-year-old son James <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/apr/27/hillsborough-families-applauded-at-liverpool-vigil-inquest">died in the Hillsborough tragedy</a>, addressed a meeting in parliament on Tuesday. She spoke at the launch of Andy Burnham’s <a href="http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/andy-burnham-proposes-major-reforms-11313170">new campaign</a> for stronger police accountability. The parliamentary and health service ombudsman (PHSO) has just <a href="http://www.ombudsman.org.uk/reports-and-consultations/reports/health/a-report-of-investigations-into-unsafe-discharge-from-hospital">published a shaming report</a> on the way vulnerable patients are sometimes discharged from hospital. Earlier in the week, health thinktank <a href="http://www.kingsfund.org.uk/blog/2016/04/readiness-to-change">the King’s Fund</a> heard that there was a serious shortage of senior managers prepared to take on the thankless task of running an NHS trust.</p><p>Each of these is important in themselves. Each of these says something troubling about how public bodies are held to account.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/hillsborough-hospitals-public-bodies">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Scientists are speaking up in debates over Brexit. So why is big business silent?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/political-science/2016/may/12/scientists-are-speaking-up-in-debates-over-brexit-so-why-is-big-business-silent</link>
      <description><p>Academics are queuing up to make the case for staying in the EU. But almost all the larger R&amp;D-intensive companies have kept their heads down. Why?</p><p>Science is a vital part of the UK’s relationship with the rest of Europe. <a href="https://royalsociety.org/news/2015/12/UK%20research%20and%20EU/">Some eighteen per cent of EU funding returned to the UK is for research</a>. The UK is a net contributor to the EU across the board, but a net beneficiary in science. Businesses are responsible for around two-thirds of research and development (R&amp;D) investment in the UK, with firms headquartered overseas making up half of that figure – by far the highest proportion among G7 countries. </p><p>Against that background, I expected business to have plenty to say during the recent inquiry into <a href="http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/lords-select/science-and-technology-committee/news-parliament-2015/eu-membership-report-published/">‘EU membership and UK science’ by the House of Lords Committee on Science and Technology</a>, for which I was the specialist advisor. Amidst lively exchanges between <a href="https://twitter.com/sciencebritain">pro-leave</a> and <a href="http://scientistsforeu.uk/">pro-remain</a> campaign groups, the House of Lords conducted a calm analysis of the evidence on the scientific dimensions of the EU debate. Around eighty written submissions and thirty expert witnesses set out arguments and analysis. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/political-science/2016/may/12/scientists-are-speaking-up-in-debates-over-brexit-so-why-is-big-business-silent">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>For passion and for purpose the next London mayor has to be Sadiq Khan</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/davehillblog/2016/may/04/for-passion-and-for-purpose-londons-next-mayor-has-to-be-sadiq-khan</link>
      <description><p>The Tory campaign has tainted the mayoralty and their candidate deserves a hammering</p><p>Imagine, if you can stand it, what it would mean if Zac Goldsmith wins the election to become London’s new mayor. The top political job in the British capital will have fallen into the hands of a man whose campaign has trawled a cesspool of smear in order to exploit deep fears and destructive prejudices. He would take office already tainted in the eyes of millions of Londoners, his credibility in ruins from the start. </p><p>It has been difficult to tell if Goldsmith’s refusal to accept that he has shamelessly misrepresented Labour’s Sadiq Khan in order to scare voters into rejecting him results from conviction or cluelessness. Either way, it proves him wholly unsuited to the task of leading a city of such comfortable cultural variety as London. At times, Goldsmith has resembled the spoiled dilettante he insists he is not, puzzled and affronted by any questioning of his right to buy and to do whatever he wants. At others, the Richmond Park MP has looked like a lost stork wondering how to get back to Kew. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/davehillblog/2016/may/04/for-passion-and-for-purpose-londons-next-mayor-has-to-be-sadiq-khan">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>BBC, ITV and migration spark shadows of outrage in Westminster</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-itv-and-migration-spark-shadows-of-outrage-in-westminster</link>
      <description><p>As the big news of the day proves to be not so big after all, MPs find themselves all worked up with nowhere to go<br></p><p>Maria Eagle was outraged. Outraged that there was almost nothing to be outraged about. After months of the “End of the World as We Know It” doomsday predictions, the culture secretary finally <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-john-whittingdale-white-paper-star-pay-board">published his white paper on the BBC</a>, and it was, if not quite business as usual, then not nearly so bad as feared. Strictly Come Dancing had been saved for the nation. There could be only one explanation; the leftwing luvvies had managed to nobble John Whittingdale.</p><p>“The fact that most of the secretary of state’s wilder proposals appear to have been watered down, dumped or delayed by the government, of which he is a member, is a reflection of his diminishing influence and lack of clout,” said the shadow culture secretary, her voice bristling with contempt. “There is no point in the secretary of state denying that he has been overruled by the prime minister and the chancellor.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/bbc-itv-and-migration-spark-shadows-of-outrage-in-westminster">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Angela Merkel is suddenly looking politically mortal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2016/may/12/angela-merkel-suddenly-looking-politically-mortal</link>
      <description><p>Will the German chancellor survive to serve another term? Should she?</p><p>Europe’s most important politician <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/10/iain-duncan-smith-cameron-let-germans-veto-emergency-brake">took a bit of a pasting from the Brexit camp this week</a> for allegedly throwing her weight around in David Cameron’s company. She has had a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/12/angela-merkel-elections-refugee-crisis-far-right">rough few months</a> since the Syrian refugee crisis hit Germany and is suddenly looking politically mortal. But does Angela Merkel deserve it? </p><p>Yes and mostly no. In these turbulent times we may miss her quietly steady hand when it’s no longer there to hold. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2016/may/12/angela-merkel-suddenly-looking-politically-mortal">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Gaziantep: home to Isis killers, sex traders… and a quest to rebuild Syria</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/08/gazientep-turkey-tamkeen-quest-to-rebuild-syria</link>
      <description>The Turkish city hosts the HQ of Tamkeen, a UK-backed aid agency reintroducing democracy to a country ravaged by civil war<p>Dragging on his American-brand cigarette, Rami al-Khatib leans back and looks away. There is a wry smile but it hints at a bubbling frustration. I have asked him whether he feels optimistic about the future. “There are two questions you should never ask a Syrian,” he says, “and that’s one of them.”</p><p>From behind a wisp of smoke, Khatib, 29, a law student at Damascus university before the conflict, adds: “The other is: where do you see yourself in five years’ time?” The young Syrian’s disdain at the line of questioning is understandable. Khatib was born in the now infamous city of Palmyra, where Isis massacred hundreds and where Vladimir Putin last week emphasised his role in winning it back for the regime by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/05/palmyra-amphitheatre-hosts-russian-concert-after-recapture-by-syrian-forces">staging a classical concert in its ruins</a>. Brought up in Homs, Khatib helped with the 2014 evacuation and watched as snipers picked off women walking through the rubble. He still has family in the city.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/may/08/gazientep-turkey-tamkeen-quest-to-rebuild-syria">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is the EU really dictating the shape of your bananas?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/boris-johnson-launches-the-vote-leave-battlebus-in-cornwall</link>
      <description><p>Boris Johnson says EU laws about vacuum cleaners and bananas are ‘crazy’. We take a look at whether he is right</p><p>Launching the Vote Leave battlebus with an impromptu speech in Cornwall, Boris Johnson <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2016/may/11/pmqs-corbyn-cameron-osborne-boris-johnson-interview-politics-live?page=with:block-5732f7aee4b0a3721d605505#block-5732f7aee4b0a3721d605505">has listed several factors he said mean the Brexit camp</a> had “right on its side” and 24 June – the day after Britain’s EU referendum – would prove to be “Independence Day for Britain”.</p><p>Brandishing a Cornish pasty (rather ironically, one of more than 60 British food and drink products that have protected geographical status under EU law, meaning they cannot be ripped off by imitations made elsewhere), Johnson said it was “absolutely crazy that the EU is telling us how powerful our vacuum cleaners have got to be, what shape our bananas have got to be, and all that kind of thing”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/boris-johnson-launches-the-vote-leave-battlebus-in-cornwall">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Rolling coverage of the London mayor, Scottish parliament, Welsh assembly, Northern Ireland assembly and English councils results </p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2016/may/06/uk-elections-sadiq-khan-ahead-in-london-mayoral-race-live-updates">UK elections: the London mayoral race and the rest of the results - live</a></li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/06/scottish-labour-facing-third-place-after-collapse-in-vote">Scottish Labour beaten into third place after Tory surge</a></li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/06/zac-goldsmith-attacked-by-senior-tory-over-tactics-in-london-mayor-election">Senior London Tory attacks Goldsmith’s campaign</a><br></li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/06/welsh-labour-might-need-coalition-to-run-next-government">Welsh Labour might need other parties’ support to govern</a></li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/06/uk-elections-at-a-glance-the-key-points">Key points of the overnight developments</a></li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/ng-interactive/2016/may/05/uk-election-results-tracker-2016">Live results tracker</a><br></li></ul><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-06T12:59:41.669Z">1.59pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Time for me to sign off too. The <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2016/may/06/uk-elections-sadiq-khan-ahead-in-london-mayoral-race-live-updates">wonderful Andrew Sparrow is back with a new live blog</a> covering the latest results and analysis. Phew!</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-06T12:57:08.722Z">1.57pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Boris Johnson has signed off as London mayor as Sadiq Khan looks almost certain to replace him. </p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">1/2 Great to have looked back on Mayoralty this AM &amp; taken your final questions on <a href="https://twitter.com/LBC">@LBC</a> <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/AskBoris?src=hash">#AskBoris</a> – thank you London for the last 8 years</p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">2/2 It’s time to sign off from City Hall – it’s been the most amazing privilege to be your Mayor. You can follow me on <a href="https://twitter.com/BorisJohnson">@BorisJohnson</a></p><p lang="en" dir="ltr">70% counted &amp; it looks as though final mayoral result will be a lot earlier than the 2354 of 2012. Khan still ahead <a href="https://t.co/pusR6yyc0K">pic.twitter.com/pusR6yyc0K</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2016/may/05/uk-election-results-2016-live-updates-and-news">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How London became a Labour city – and what it means for British politics</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/how-london-became-a-labour-city-and-what-it-means-for-british-politics</link>
      <description><p>Sadiq Khan’s crushing victory in the mayoral election has confirmed the party’s dominance in the capital. Is it time to stop treating London’s political stance as a weird anomaly?</p><p>The constituency office of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/profile/emily-thornberry">Emily Thornberry</a>, Labour MP for Islington South and Finsbury, is a low, workaday building with barred windows. In a part of London that has been gentrifying for half a century, it looks out of place. Many of the tall Georgian terraces on the street have been expensively restored and extended. Most of the cars are BMWs. Bankers eat duck in the pub down the road.</p><p>The first time Thornberry stood for the seat, in 2005, Labour was in the early stages of an electoral decline that has continued in most parts of Britain ever since. She won by a flimsy 484 votes. As the 2010 election approached, it was widely assumed that she was doomed. “A lot of my activists went to bookies up and down the [nearby] Holloway Road,” she remembers, “because the odds you could get on me winning were so good.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/how-london-became-a-labour-city-and-what-it-means-for-british-politics">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>UK must leave European convention on human rights, says Theresa May</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/apr/25/uk-must-leave-european-convention-on-human-rights-theresa-may-eu-referendum</link>
      <description><p>Critics condemn home secretary’s remarks, which put her on collision course with cabinet colleagues</p><p>• <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/video/2016/apr/25/patrick-stewart-sketch-what-has-the-echr-ever-done-for-us-video">Patrick Stewart sketch: what has the ECHR done for us?</a></p><p>Britain should withdraw from the European convention on human rights regardless of the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/politics/eu-referendum">EU referendum</a> result, Theresa May has said, in comments that contradict ministers within her own government.<br></p><p>The shadow justice secretary, Charles Falconer, said he was appalled by the home secretary’s comments, which he described as “so ignorant, so illiberal, so misguided”, while the Tory MP and former attorney general Dominic Grieve said he was disappointed by the intervention. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/apr/25/uk-must-leave-european-convention-on-human-rights-theresa-may-eu-referendum">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Carwyn Jones and Leanne Wood tied in battle to become Welsh first minister</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/carwyn-jones-leanne-wood-tied-welsh-first-minister</link>
      <description><p>Labour’s Jones fails to get re-elected as Tory and Ukip members’ votes for leader of Plaid Cymru result in 29-29 draw</p><p>The Labour party has been faced with deadlock in the Welsh assembly after an informal coalition of Plaid Cymru, the Conservatives and Ukip successfully blocked a vote to reappoint Carwyn Jones as the country’s first minister. </p><p>The leader of Plaid Cymru, Leanne Wood, was able to draw level with Jones in the vote on Wednesday, with 29 assembly members each. The nationalist leader received the unlikely support of other parties who won seats from Labour in the recent local elections, including the Tories and Ukip.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/carwyn-jones-leanne-wood-tied-welsh-first-minister">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>David Cameron says his EU campaign is Project Fact, not Project Fear</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/feb/29/cameron-dismisses-claims-project-fear-eu-remain-negative</link>
      <description><p>PM responds to accusations of referendum scare tactics, saying: ‘Stay in and you know what you’ll get’</p><p>David Cameron has styled himself the leader of “Project Fact”, dismissing claims that he is trying to scare voters into remaining in the EU.</p><p>The prime minister, who has repeatedly characterised a decision to leave the EU as a “leap in the dark”, has been accused of playing up the risks of Brexit in a strategy dubbed “Project Fear”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/feb/29/cameron-dismisses-claims-project-fear-eu-remain-negative">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>'Women should not expect government help over pension changes'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/stephen-crabb-says-it-is-impossible-to-unwind-womens-pensions-changes</link>
      <description><p>Stephen Crabb says it is not possible to unwind changes to the state pension age that mean women stand to lose out</p><p>Women who stand to lose thousands of pounds because of increases to the state pension age should not expect the government to intervene, the work and pensions secretary, Stephen Crabb, has told MPs.</p><p>Campaigners say women born in the 1950s will be left out of pocket by a government decision made five years ago to speed up the phasing in of an increase from 60 to 66 in the age at which women can retire.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/11/stephen-crabb-says-it-is-impossible-to-unwind-womens-pensions-changes">Continue reading...</a></description>
